sourceString: Preliminary Estimates of the Prevalence of Selected Underlying Health Conditions Among Patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019 — United States, February 12–March 28, 2020
targetString: Caciaax guec m5 tst f]n kv t11 ju1th th5n kv ciaax pusl` pu11ny nath t5 cv k`p kv juey ksrsnabayr`th 2019 k` Yunaytet Y5tht22t kv 12 –pay di]k 28, 2020

sourceString: On March 11, 2020, the World Health Organization declared Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) a pandemic.

sourceString: As of March 28, 2020, a total of 571,678 confirmed COVID-19 cases and 26,494 deaths have been reported worldwide.

sourceString: Reports from China and Italy suggest that risk factors for severe disease include older age and the presence of at least one of several underlying health conditions.

sourceString: U.S. older adults, including those aged ≥65 years and particularly those aged ≥85 years, also appear to be at higher risk for severe COVID-19–associated outcomes; however, data describing underlying health conditions among U.S. COVID-19 patients have not yet been reported.
targetString: D5t U.S. kvvl kv tin we runkivn k` ≥65 kv tin we runkivn k` ≥85 vl]x b` cv jssc vn f66 kv kvn j5 rik` COVID-19 tin tusskv k` kv; kuv la f6 l``r nyoothv jv 5 ju1th tin wen pu1nyn5 nath v jvn d55t U.S. J5 ju1th COVID-19 xot kv /k1n kv n5 lar.

sourceString: As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have reported 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom data on underlying health conditions and other known risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections were reported.
targetString: Kv gu11th m5 cet paydi]k 28,2020, w55n U.S. kvn k2thn5 kv cu kvn pek m5122,653 lar k` U.S. Pek COVID-19 k` CDC, kvvl kv7,162 (5.8%) t22 ca l``r kv ciaax ju1thn5 tin k]x jek k` kv kvvl kv rik k]kivn kv min tusk kv juey l55k` cua kv lar.

sourceString: Among these 7,162 cases, 2,692 (37.6%) patients had one or more underlying health condition or risk factor, and 4,470 (62.4%) had none of these conditions reported.
targetString: Rvidivn pek m5 7,162 , pek 2,692 (37.6%) k` j5 ju1th te raan kv juey kvl kiv rvw n5 wen m5 reep rivk, k` pek m5 4,470 (62.4%) thilv kv kvn rik titi.

sourceString: The percentage of COVID-19 patients with at least one underlying health condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1,037, 71%) than that among those who were not hospitalized (1,388 of 5,143, 27%).
targetString: Vn pvrthvntvj j5 ju1th COVID-19 tin te raak kv jueydv kvl n5 wen cuv d5t k` tin g77r raan yoop m5 d55t (ICU) kv(358 of 457, 78%) k` tin g77r t]]c dueelwal v thil ICU kv(732 of 1,037, 71%) t v b``l pek m5(1,388 of 5,143, 27%) tin /k1n ts11c dueelwal.

sourceString: The most commonly reported conditions were diabetes mellitus, chronic lung disease, and cardiovascular disease.
targetString: Ju1th tin cu xuan k` kv tin lat kv v juey thok22r mullituth, ju1y lsaac m5 c5 j``ny kv juey pu]]th m5 c5 j``ny.

sourceString: These preliminary findings suggest that in the United States, persons with underlying health conditions or other recognized risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections appear to be at a higher risk for severe disease from COVID-19 than are persons without these conditions.
targetString: Kvn l``r5 ti kvl titi nyooth kvnv rvi Yunaytet Y5tht22t vn f66 naath tin te kv ju1th k]kivn n5 wen kiv rik k]kivn t5 ca x1c k` luex l55k` la te kv rvi rik` ju1th COVID-19 v b``l min tusk k` naath tin thil ju1th k]kivn n5 wen.

sourceString: Data from laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases reported to CDC from 50 states, four U.S. territories and affiliated islands, the District of Columbia, and New York City with February 12–March 28, 2020 onset dates were analyzed.
targetString: L``r m5 be k` lab cv jv x`th vn f66 pek COVID-19 in ca l1r CDC rvi w55n5 t5 50, w55n xuan k` U.S. kvn dhu]]l5, kv wec Columbia, kv New York th5t5 kv pay rvw 12-paydi]k 28, 2020 kv c`xn5 cua kv guic.

sourceString: Cases among persons repatriated to the United States from Wuhan, China, and the Diamond Princess cruise ship were excluded.

sourceString: For cases with missing onset dates, date of onset was estimated by subtracting 4 days (median interval from symptom onset to specimen collection date among cases with known dates in these data) from the earliest specimen collection.
targetString: Kv pek k` /k1n lark v tuk n5n5, c`x in tusk kv kv cua kv mar kv xu]k n5n5 d1x xuaan (kam tuk`nyuuthn5 kv c`x in ca x1c v we k` k1n k11k tin waa thvm rvi k` pek in ca x1th) kv c`x in l1t th2m kv jv.

sourceString: Public health departments reported cases to CDC using a standardized case report form that captures information (yes, no, or unknown) on the following conditions and potential risk factors: chronic lung disease (inclusive of asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], and emphysema); diabetes mellitus; cardiovascular disease; chronic renal disease; chronic liver disease; immunocompromised condition; neurologic disorder, neurodevelopmental, or intellectual disability; pregnancy; current smoking status; former smoking status; or other chronic disease.
targetString: Mukt`p pusl` pu11ny nath dial cuv pek ` tin tusk k1m CDC kv du]]p l``r5 min ca l1t kv gu11thdv kv wargak in k1p kv l``r5 (h]]n, h22y kiv x1c kv) kv titi tin tusk kv rik kv: juey pu]]th m5 c5 j``ny, juey lsaac m5 c5 j``ny [CORD], kvn emphysema); juey thok22r mellituth, ju1th lsaac, juey rokn5 m5 c5 j``ny, juey cu1ny m5 c5 j``ny, ciaax bum` pu11ny m5 ca gvr; rivk r``l xith`; ciaax pieth r``l xith`, kiv ciaax dak` p0l` c`r` wec, ru2t, pek m1th ran kv tap kv jvn gu11th vmv, pek m1th tap`; kiv ju1th k]kivn tin c5 j``ny pu]]ny ran.

sourceString: Data reported to CDC are preliminary and can be updated by health departments over time; critical data elements might be missing at the time of initial report; thus, this analysis is descriptive, and no statistical comparisons could be made.
targetString: L``r5 t5 ca K1m CDC kuiy kv k` de kv nysk kv l`t mukt`p pusl` pu11ny kv gu11th m5 b`l; l``r5 tin d5t d]x dee kv thil kv gu11th th7p` l``r5 min nhiam; ins vn guec lat`divn in nhiam k` thilv p``rivn m5 d22 l1t.

sourceString: The percentages of patients of all ages with underlying health conditions who were not hospitalized, hospitalized without ICU admission, and hospitalized with ICU admission were calculated.
targetString: Pek j5 ju1th k` run diaal tin te kv ju1th k]kivn n5 wen tin /k1n ts11c dueelwal, tin ca ts11c dueelwal v thil ICU, kv tin ca ts11c kv ICU cua kvn diaal du`c.

sourceString: Percentages of hospitalizations with and without ICU admission were estimated for persons aged ≥19 years with and without underlying health conditions.
targetString: Pek in ca ts11c v thil ICU cua jv guic kv naath tin runkivn ≥19 v thil ju1th k]kivn n5 wen kvvvl vk tin t22 ju1th k]kivn n5 wen.

sourceString: This part of the analysis was limited to persons aged ≥19 years because of the small sample size of cases in children with reported underlying health conditions (N = 32).
targetString: Vn k1th vmv k` guecdivn cuv peek k` naath tin runkivn ≥19 kv f66 kuiy pek in ca n66x k` gaat tin tsaatn5 tin ca lar 5 te kv ju1th k]kivn n5 wen (N = 32).

sourceString: To account for missing data among these preliminary reports, ranges were estimated with a lower bound including cases with both known and unknown status for hospitalization with and without ICU admission as the denominator and an upper bound using only cases with known outcome status as the denominator.
targetString: Kv guec l``r5 tin te j]]r rvi l``r` mv tst vmv, cua kam t]t] du`c kv r6m m5 kuiy kv rvw; min c1c kv kvn min tin ku`c kv kv ciaax t11c`divn dueelwal v ICU kiv thil ICU v la dinsm5nvtsr kvn r6m in te nhial kv pek in x1c kv k`rsa kv ben r5sulk` raar v la d5nsm5nvtsr.

sourceString: Because of small sample size and missing data on underlying health conditions among COVID-19 patients who died, case-fatality rates for persons with and without underlying conditions were not estimated.

sourceString: As of March 28, 2020, a total of 122,653 laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases (Figure) and 2,112 deaths were reported to CDC.

sourceString: Case report forms were submitted to CDC for 74,439 (60.7%) cases.

sourceString: Data on presence or absence of underlying health conditions and other recognized risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections (i.e., smoking and pregnancy) were available for 7,162 (5.8%) patients (Table 1).
targetString: L``r kv thil ju1thn5 tin wen kvn t11divn th5n kvvl kv xsak tin k]x tin nyin rikn5 kv min n77x d5t ju1th luex` l55k` (cet kv m1th tap` kvn ru2t) cua kv jek kv pek m5 7,162 (5.8%) k` j5 ju1th (Tharbet 1).

sourceString: Approximately one third of these patients (2,692, 37.6%), had at least one underlying condition or risk factor.
targetString: Cetv kv m5 pek m5 kvl w55k` di]k (2,692, 37.6%), k` j5 ju1th t22 kv juey kvn kiv rvw n5 wen kv ciaax rik`dv.

sourceString: Diabetes mellitus (784, 10.9%), chronic lung disease (656, 9.2%), and cardiovascular disease (647, 9.0%) were the most frequently reported conditions among all cases.
targetString: Juey thok22r mellituth(784, 10.9%), juey pu]]th m5 c5 j``ny (656, 9.2%), kv juey lsaac m5 c5 j``ny(647, 9.0%) cu kv xuan rvi l``r` k` naath t5 xuan.

sourceString: Among 457 ICU admissions and 1,037 non-ICU hospitalizations, 358 (78%) and 732 (71%), respectively occurred among persons with one or more reported underlying health condition.
targetString: Rvi nath t5 457 t5 ca ts11c kv ICU kvn t5 1,037 t5 ca ts11c v thil ICU pek m5 358 (78%) kvn pek m5 732 (71%), 5ns cuv tussk rvi nath tin te kv juey kvl kiv rvw n5 wev rvi civvx`dv.

sourceString: In contrast, 1,388 of 5,143 (27%) COVID-19 patients who were not hospitalized were reported to have at least one underlying health condition.
targetString: Vgu1c kv nvmv, pek m5 1,388 k` pek m5 5,143 (27%) k` naath tin cv moc COVID-19 cuv tey /k1n kv ts11c k` /k1n kv lar 5 te kvn kv ju1th k]kivn n5 wen.

sourceString: Among patients aged ≥19 years, the percentage of non-ICU hospitalizations was higher among those with underlying health conditions (27.3%–29.8%) than among those without underlying health conditions (7.2%–7.8%); the percentage of cases that resulted in an ICU admission was also higher for those with underlying health conditions (13.3%–14.5%) than those without these conditions (2.2%–2.4%) (Table 2).
targetString: Rvi j5 ju1th tin runkivn ≥19 pek in ca ts11c v thil ICU cu d5tn5 jvn k` naath tin te kv ju1th k]kivn n5 wen kv pek m5 (27.3%–29.8%) v b``l min tussk k` naath tin thi lju1th k]kivn n5 wen kv pek m5 (7.2%–7.8%); vn pvfrthvntvj k` pek nath tin c5 we k` ICU cuv d5t b` k` naath tin te kv ju1th k]kivn n5 wen kv pek m5 (13.3%–14.5%) v b``l min tussk k` naath tin thil ju1th k]kivn n5 wen kv pek m5 cet kv(2.2%–2.4%) (Thatbet).

sourceString: Small numbers of COVID-19 patients aged < 19 years were reported to be hospitalized (48) or admitted to an ICU (eight).
targetString: Pek m5 tst k` naath tin cv moc COVID-19 tin runkivn < 19 cua kv lar 5 ca kv ts11c (48) kiv ca kv ts11c kv ICU (8).

sourceString: In contrast, 335 patients aged < 19 years were not hospitalized and 1,342 had missing data on hospitalization.
targetString: V gu1c kv nvmv, pek m5 k` 335 j5 ju1th t5 runkivn < 19 t5 /k1n ts11c kvn pek m5 1,342 m5 ca ts11c cu l``r kv ku5cdivn thil.

sourceString: Among all COVID-19 patients with complete information on underlying conditions or risk factors, 184 deaths occurred (all among patients aged ≥19 years); 173 deaths (94%) were reported among patients with at least one underlying condition.
targetString: Rvi j5 ju1th COVID-19 diaal tin ca l``r m5 thi`x jek kv ku5 cdivn kv ciaax ju1thn5 tin k]kivn tin te kv kv n5 wen, cu naath t5 184 l5w (94%) rvi j5 ju1th tin te raan kv juey d]divn n5 wen.

sourceString: Among 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases reported to CDC as of March 28, 2020, 7,162 (5.8%) patients had data available pertaining to underlying health conditions or potential risk factors; among these patients, higher percentages of patients with underlying conditions were admitted to the hospital and to an ICU than patients without reported underlying conditions.
targetString: Rvi nath t5 122,653 k` U.S. Pek in ca l1r CDC k` j5 ju1th COVID-19 kv gu11th paay di]k 28, 2020, v naath t5 7,162 (5.8%) t5 te l``r kv ku5cdivn th5n kv ciaax ju1thn5 tin k]x n5 wen, rvi j5 ju1th titi, pek in d55t k` naath tin te kv ju1th k]kivn n5 wen cua kv ts11c kv ICU v b``l naath tin ca lar 5 thil ju1th k]kivn n5 wen .

sourceString: These results are consistent with findings from China and Italy, which suggest that patients with underlying health conditions and risk factors, including, but not limited to, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, COPD, coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, chronic renal disease, and smoking, might be at higher risk for severe disease or death from COVID-19.
targetString: Kvn titi we kv kvvl kv min ca jek b` k` China kvn Tiliaan, min nyooth f66 j5 ju1th tin raan kv jueydv k]divn n5 wen m5 x]]x jv rvi teek`dv cet kv juey thok22r mellituth, d5t rivm, CORD, ju1th r``l ksrsnvvr5, ju1th xith` thvr5bsrsbathkulsr, juey rokn5 m5 c5 j``ny, kv m1th tap` kv kvn naath tin la te kv rivk kiv b5 l5w kv juey COVID-19.

sourceString: This analysis was limited by small numbers and missing data because of the burden placed on reporting health departments with rapidly rising case counts, and these findings might change as additional data become available.
targetString: Vn guec vmvm cuv p22k k` naath t5 tst kv f66 thilv l``r m5 r7x kvn f66 cv thiak w55 mukt`p` pusl` pu11ny vn f66 ba l``r malv n66x kv rvc kv ku2n kv pek in k``p jueyv, kv f66 ns kvn l``r5 titi d]x b5 kv rs gvr m5 ca l``r5 k]kivn nysk kv jek.

sourceString: It is not yet known whether the severity or level of control of underlying health conditions affects the risk for severe disease associated with COVID-19.
targetString: Xotv /k1nv n5 x1c m5 b5 d5t kiv pek g1x ju1thn5 tin te pu1nyn5 nath n5 wen m5 bv ciaax rik` kv juey COVID-19 rep.

sourceString: Many of these underlying health conditions are common in the United States: based on self-reported 2018 data, the prevalence of diagnosed diabetes among U.S. adults was 10.1%, and the U.S. age-adjusted prevalence of all types of heart disease (excluding hypertension without other heart disease) was 10.6% in 2017.
targetString: Ju1th t5 xuan k` kvn ti te pu1nyn5 nath n5 wen ti kvn xuan kv Yunaytet Y5tht22t: kv l``r 2 ca lar kv 2018, pek in ca jek kv juey thok22r kv dsx US v 10.1% k` ju1th lsaac k` U.S. tin la tussk d5t kv kvn d5t rivm v thil ju1th k]kivn (cua 10.6%) kv ru]]n 2017.

sourceString: The age-adjusted prevalence of COPD among U.S. adults is 5.9%, and in 2018, the U.S. estimated prevalence of current asthma among persons of all ages was 7.9%.
targetString: R2p ju1th CORD kv rs xuan run5 k` dsx US v 5.9% kv ru]]n 2018, cu U.S. v diw 5 r2p ju1th adhuma nvmv kv rs k` run diaal k` naath cua 7.9%.

sourceString: CDC continues to develop and update resources for persons with underlying health conditions to reduce the risk of acquiring COVID-19.
targetString: CDC ucv xot kv m5 l`tv kuak k` kapv kv nhial kv ku5c nath tin te kv ju1th k]kivn n5 wen kv f66 bv li11 nath kv COVID-19 xot.

sourceString: The estimated higher prevalence of these conditions among those in this early group of U.S. COVID-19 patients and the potentially higher risk for more severe disease from COVID-19 associated with the presence of underlying conditions highlight the importance of COVID-19 prevention in persons with underlying conditions.
targetString: Pek in d55t in ca nvn kv ciaax ju1thn5 tin te th5n n5 wen k` j5 U.S. kv jvn bu]n vmv J5 ju1th COVID-19 kvn naath tin thi1k rivk kv pu]nydivn in we kvvl kv juey COVID-19 kvvl kvn ju1th tin te th5n n5 wen nyoothv bu]m kv ciaax in d22 gax naath tin te kv ju1th n5 wen.

sourceString: The findings in this report are subject to at least six limitations.
targetString: Kvn tin ca jek k` l``r vmv te kvn kv diw kv dup b1kvl.

sourceString: First, these data are preliminary, and the analysis was limited by missing data related to the health department reporting burden associated with rapidly rising case counts and delays in completion of information requiring medical chart review; these findings might change as additional data become available.
targetString: Kv nhiam, l``r5 titi kvn kuiy kv, k` guecdivn kuiyv kv f66 te l``r5 t5 xuan j]]r k` mukt`p pusl` pu11ny kv thiaak k` min ca l1th w55dv kv f66 b5 l``r5 mal dhil ben rvc kv p0th kvn j1ny kv thu]k l``r5 tin d22 we jek m5d5ksl cat; kvn titi tin ca jek d]x ba rs gvr m5 ca l``r5 k]kivn nysk kv jek.

sourceString: Information on underlying conditions was only available for 7,162 (5.8%) of 122,653 cases reported to CDC.
targetString: L``r kv ku5c ju1thn5 tin te th5n n5 wen te kv th5n v la 7,162 (5.8%) k` 122,653 t5 tst k`] tin ca l1r CDC.

sourceString: It cannot be assumed that those with missing information are similar to those with data on either hospitalizations or underlying health conditions.
targetString: /Ca jv dee met lar vn f66 naath tin te kv ju1th k]kivn n5 wen tin /k1n jek 5 kvn p``r kv kv tin ca l``r5kivn jek tin ca ts11c kiv tin te kv ju1th k]kivn.

sourceString: Second, these data are subject to bias in outcome ascertainment because of short follow-up time.
targetString: Rvwdv, kvn l``r5 titi d22 rvidivn te kac kv ben raar x`th` kv f66 kuiy gu11th in gu]]r kv kv kv jv.

sourceString: Some outcomes might be underestimated, and long-term outcomes cannot be assessed in this analysis.
targetString: Th11x ben`divn raar d]x ca kv guic v kuiy, k` tin b` raar kv gu11th m5 b``r thilv gu11th m5 d22 jrk kv rvi guec vmv.

sourceString: Third, because of the limited availability of testing in many jurisdictions during this period, this analysis is likely biased toward more severe cases, and findings might change as testing becomes more widespread.
targetString: Di]]kdivn, kv f66 kuiy pek in th0m kv rvi gu1thn5 lu]]kn5 t5 xuan, vn guec vmv thi1k f66 derv te kv kac rvidv kv ku5c nath tin d5t jueydivn, k` min ca jek derv rs gvr m5 c5 th2m d5t k` naath.

sourceString: Fourth, because of the descriptive nature of these data, attack rates among persons with and without underlying health conditions could not be compared, and thus the risk difference of severe disease with COVID-19 between these groups could not be estimated.
targetString: Xuaandivn, kv f66 t11 lar`divn kv l``r5 titi, ban kvn pek in ca lar k` naath tin thil kv ju1th k]kivn n5 wen v /ca kv dee p11r, k` 5ns d``k rik` ju1th in d55t k` COVID-19 kam bun5 tit /ca jv dee lu`x kv m1r.

sourceString: Fifth, no conclusions could be drawn about underlying conditions that were not included in the case report form or about different conditions that were reported in a single, umbrella category.

sourceString: Finally, for some underlying health conditions and risk factors, including neurologic disorders, chronic liver disease, being a current smoker, and pregnancy, few severe outcomes were reported; therefore, conclusions cannot be drawn about the risk for severe COVID-19 among persons in these groups.

sourceString: Persons in the United States with underlying health conditions appear to be at higher risk for more severe COVID-19, consistent with findings from other countries.

sourceString: With the COVID-19 outbreak, PHE and RCGP RSC have adapted existing influenza surveillance to monitor the spread of COVID-19 in the community, and this protocol sets out the basis for that collaboration.

sourceString: The aim of this study is to identify whether there is undetected community transmission of COVID-19, estimate population susceptibility, and monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community.

sourceString: The objectives of this study are as follows:

sourceString: The methods will follow the approach used in the current influenza surveillance system and recent serology study, and includes five components: (1) primary care clinical surveillance; (2) virological surveillance; (3) population serological surveillance; (4) convalescent sera in cases; and (5) data curation.

sourceString: The NHS uses the Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) system of coding, which is normally only updated twice annually.

sourceString: The key requirements for this release were the ability to code (Table 4) a case of COVID-19, exposure to risk of infection (travel to an area where there may be a higher risk), contact with anyone infected with COVID-19, a report that a person had been tested for COVID-19, and that the disease had been excluded (likely a negative test).

sourceString: From the start, we will be carefully curating data to ensure that it can be used for future studies.

sourceString: To facilitate this our data set is listed with Health Data Research UK and the European Health Data Evidence Network.

sourceString: The statistical methodology is in support of a policy approach to widespread disease outbreak, where so-called nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) are used to respond to an emerging pandemic to produce disease suppression.

sourceString: This policy aims to reduce contact rates in the population and thereby reduce transmission of the virus.

sourceString: To implement this the UK government has recently articulated the desire to implement population self-isolation measures.

sourceString: By targeting the reproduction number (R) (the average number of secondary cases each case generates) and aiming to reduce the R to below 1, the policy seeks to reduce case numbers to low levels or (as seen in previous outbreaks with severe acute respiratory syndrome and Ebola) to eliminate human-to-human transmission.
targetString: Kv loc wecnath k` pek in reepv rs (R) (vn pek ku00n5 tin nyin thvnd22r5 pek kvl kv min cv n66x) kvn lot c`r` k` xu]k R v we piny 1, kvn naath g77r puslvth5n5 kv xu]kdivn kv ku00n v we piny kiv (cet kv min ca nvn kv gu11th 2 nhiam 2 c5 ju1th fsw thi`x kv pek m5 d55t k` juey l55k` min rup-rup kvn Ebola) kv f66 ba d6p ran jv k` ram in d]x k`p cu]x.

sourceString: As the experience from the 2009 H1N1 pandemic has shown, NPIs can be a crucial component of pandemic mitigation.

sourceString: Key to the focus of our study will be the estimation of peak cases in the population and continual monitoring by data collection and modelling the potential growth and emergence of subsequent peaks in new cases as social distancing measures are relaxed.

sourceString: There has already been publication of important disease epidemiological measures concerning the outbreak of COVID-19 in mainland China.

sourceString: A further fundamental measure in pandemic dynamics is the length of time from infection to when a person is infectious to others and the mean duration of infectiousness.

sourceString: We intend to apply approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) to (possibly spatially heterogeneous) Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR) stochastic epidemic models.

sourceString: Such techniques are highly parallelizable and have been successfully applied to many fields including disease transmission modelling.
targetString: Jvn t11 m5 c2t kv ns jvn /cv gsaa v l7xk` jvn cv w22 gsaa kv t11 in d22 ju2y vms jak` w2 k` rad]divn.

sourceString: They are particularly suited to situations where likelihood functions are absent and where more traditional approaches such as Markov chain Monte Carlo are impractical.
targetString: Kvn gsw kv v civk kv ciaax min cetv kv m5 ca lust k` du]]r jak` p`k kvn min ca ciaax 2 wal cet kv dux Markov cin Monte Carlo jak` thil gu11th.

sourceString: Such an approach has been demonstrated to work effectively on the ASPREN surveillance data, a network of sentinel GPs and nurse practitioners who report deidentified information on ILIs and other conditions, where issues such as missing data and the need to model the observation process itself has been successfully addressed.
targetString: Kvn c11p titi ca kv nyu]]th vn f66 l`t kvn v gsaa k` ASPREN kv g1x l``r5, nvtw`k GPs n5 thvt5mvn kvn n``rthn5 tin g77r x55c tin laar thil xiec l``r` kv ILI kvn xsak tin k]x, tin la tussk xsak th5n cet kv l``r5 tin thil kvn g6r k` f66 du]]p guec l1t pu]nydv ca jv lat kv gu11thdv.

sourceString: Furthermore, peaks in new cases have been estimated by distributional methods.

sourceString: Estimates of the parameters of the SEIR model are tractable on large data sets because of parallelizability, and these methods have been implemented in several R libraries; we intend to use the libraries ABSEIR (deposited on GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) and abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) to estimate epidemic measures on a weekly basis.

sourceString: Since we are fitting an SIR-epidemic model in the ABC routine, we anticipate that our results will be robust against weekly case data containing relatively small counts.

sourceString: For example, see for the ABC methodology applied to the Tristan da Cunha common cold data from 1967, where counts of I (number of infectious cases) and R (number of recovered cases) are in the tens at most.

sourceString: Finally, in addition to the above methodology we will employ the Kaplan-Meier method with two outcomes (death and recovery) to estimate the case fatality ratio.

sourceString: This protocol describes how we have adapted a national influenza surveillance system to monitor community spread of an unexpected infection of COVID-19.

sourceString: Our testing of low-risk patients will also inform whether the containment strategy that is based on virology testing of high-risk patients and their contacts plus self-isolation is effective.

sourceString: Containment should slow the spread, and there may be benefits in the management of spread from intense surveillance.

sourceString: The proclamation specifically said "the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States constitutes a national emergency" and said the national emergency began on March 1, almost two weeks before the proclamation itself.

sourceString: The United States Department of Health and Human Services declared the outbreak a "public health emergency" on January 31.
targetString: Vn muktp` pusl` pu11ny kvn l1t ku5c gata ran k` Yunaytet Yitht22t cuv thi`x ju1th kv fsw lar 5 ca rivk wec m5 rup-rup kv pay kvl 31.

sourceString: Trump did not place the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in charge of the government's response to COVID-19, which Politico reported left some experts in disaster management disappointed.
targetString: Trump /kenv Pedvrsl emvrjvnth5 Manajvmvnt ajvnth5 (FEMA) k1m l1t kv ciaax in loc kuumv jv min tussk k` COVID-19 m22 c5 Politko in ca lar jv b11ny raar kv naath tin x`c du]]r kv yu]p rik` lscdivn jak` ji`k.

sourceString: Politico quoted Tim Manning, formerly a deputy administrator at FEMA, as saying "FEMA has an important role in coordinating the larger response to the crisis" and "[i]f there's an emergency, FEMA needs to be involved."
targetString: Cu Politiko jv lar 5 c5 Tim Mannix, ku``r in rvwdv m22 nhiam k` FEMA jv lar 5 FEMA t22 kv lu1x m5 d55t rvi r7m` civxn5 tin lusc kv rivk m5 c5 tussk k` [m5] t22 kv m5 rup-rup FEMA derv l`t th5n.

sourceString: Trump made the decision under provisions of the National Emergencies Act, amongst other governing authorities.
targetString: Cu Trump c1r k11m raar kv rvi xutn5 tin nax rs kv rik tin ru]p-ru]]p, cuv nyin lu`x` k]kivn p`l.

sourceString: The Trump administration also announced other efforts in response to COVID-19, including waiving the interest it collects on federal student loans and increasing U.S. strategic oil reserve oil purchases.
targetString: Kuumv Trump b` cuv jv lar 5 dup k]kivn tin dee nyieeny kv naath kv COVID-19 cet kv g6r nh6k nath kv in cv n66x k` d2n gan du22lg]r` k` P2dvrsl kv r2p k` c``p t]w` j`th` kvn kskdv.

sourceString: Impact of the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic on education
targetString: Rivk in ca n66x v thi1x ksrsnabayr`th kv fsw kv 2019-20 rvi du22lg]r`

sourceString: The 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic has affected educational systems worldwide, leading to the widespread closures of schools and universities.
targetString: Thi1x ksrsnabayr`th kv fsw kv 2019-20 cvciaax du22lg]r` y1r w55 mu]]n kvvliw, cv du2lg]r` kvn yun5b77thvt5n5 jak` g1kv gu1thn5 diaal.

sourceString: As of 8 April 2020, approximately 1.716 billion learners have been affected due to school closures in response to COVID-19.
targetString: Kv gu11th m5 cet kv 8 pay xuaan 2020, pek m5 cet kv bathdssr5 t5 1.716 k` gs11r cuv gs1rivn y1r kv ku5c g`k` du2l5g]r` kvn yun5b7thvt5n5 kv ku5c COVID-19.

sourceString: According to UNESCO monitoring, 188 countries have implemented nationwide closures and 5 have implemented local closures, impacting about 99.4%  of the world's student population.
targetString: Cet kv m5 ca lar v UNESCO, w55 t5 v188 cua jv lat vn f66 ba du2g]r` diaal rvi wec g1k k` w55 5 nyinkivn g1k k`r], cuv naath t5 99.4% k` gaat tin g]r du2lg]r`divn ji``k.

sourceString: On 23 March 2020, Cambridge International Examinations (CIE) released a statement announcing the cancellation of Cambridge IGCSE, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, and Cambridge Pre-U examinations for the May/June 2020 series across all countries.
targetString: Kv 23 pay di]k 2020, cu mukt`p f]]n5 wecmu]]n K0mb5r5j (CIE) jv lar cv IGCSE K0mb5r5j p`l, pek K0mb5r5j O, kv K0mb5r5j AS kvn amp wec mu]]n; kv pek A, kv K0mb5r5j AICE Diploma kv f]]n K0mb5r5j pre- U kv pay dhieec/pay b1kvl 2020 v guur r] rvi w55n5 diaal.

sourceString: International Baccalaureate exams have also been cancelled.School closures impact not only students, teachers, and families, but have far-reaching economic and societal consequences.
targetString: F]]n5 Baccalaureate w55 mu]]n cua kv p`l b`. G1k du2l5g]r`/cv ji`k k` gaat tin g]r k`r], xieec, kvn di22th gan, jvn b` copv gu1th diaal k` eksnsmik kvn wec kvvl.

sourceString: School closures in response to COVID-19 have shed light on various social and economic issues, including student debt, digital learning, food insecurity, and homelessness, as well as access to childcare, health care, housing, internet, and disability services.
targetString: G1k du2l5g]r` kv ku5c COVID-19 cv cop k` civx eksnsmik` t5 xuan, cet kv d2n k` gaat tin g]r, g]1r kv d5j5tsl, dak ku1n, kvn thil tiecn5 tin civx kv kvvl kv thil yoop` gan, ciaax yop` pusl` pu11ny, jek tiecn5, intvrnvt, kvn l`t kv ku5c nath tin j5 bumn5.

sourceString: The impact was more severe for disadvantaged children and their families, causing interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems, and consequent economic cost to families who could not work.In response to school closures, UNESCO recommended the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.
targetString: Vn ciaax ji``k vmv cv ben d5t vl]x k` gaat tin thil m5 gsaa m5 jekv kvvl kv die22thkivn, cv g]1r jak` xussk, c5 ku`n thil, cv rivk yoop` gan rep k` cv ji``k eksnsmik` n66x kv di22th gan tin thil m5 l0l l1t v kvn. Kv ku5c g`k` du2l5g]r`, cu UNESCO jv lar 5 r5t g]r` k` gs1r v n1n kvn gs1r v f66x in dee du2lg]r` kvn xieec jv l1t kv f66 b5 nath gs1r v n1n kv f66 ba xu]kdivn kv du2lg]r`divn jak` kuiy.

sourceString: Efforts to stem the spread of COVID-19 through non-pharmaceutical interventions and preventive measures such as social-distancing and self-isolation have prompted the widespread closure of primary, secondary, and tertiary schooling in over 100 countries.Previous outbreaks of infectious diseases have prompted widespread school closings around the world, with varying levels of effectiveness.
targetString: F]n lu`x` kv f66 ba thi1x COVID-19 kv fsw xok kv du]]p m5 /c5 ms du]]p wal kvn ciaax g1x nath kv rs cet cu]x kv kam kvn f66 dee raan nyuur gu11thdv k`rsa v jvn n77x g1k du2l5g]r` ms w55 mu]]n v tookv k` du2lg]r` p5raym22r5, thvkvnd22r5, kvn ter5civvr5 rvi w55n5 t5 b``l 100. Thi1x ju1th kv fsw kv gu1th t22 c5 we k` ju1th t22 nhiam cuv g1k du2l5g]r` n66x w55 mu]]n kvvliw, civx t5 g66l rvi w55n5.

sourceString: Mathematical modelling has shown that transmission of an outbreak may be delayed by closing schools.
targetString: Kv du`c in du1c jv kv m0thm5tik nyoothv jv d6p ju1th derv ku00 m5 ca du2lg]r` g1k.

sourceString: However, effectiveness depends on the contacts children maintain outside of school.
targetString: Kuv la f66 ciaax derv kith naath w22 kvvl kv t11 in tit gaatv gueerivn kv rs min c5 kv ben raar du22lg]r`.

sourceString: School closures may be effective when enacted promptly.
targetString: G1k du122lg]r` derv gsaa m5 ca jv nax kv gu11th in g77rv.

sourceString: If school closures occur late relative to an outbreak, they are less effective and may not have any impact at all.
targetString: G1k du22lg]r` la tuskv kv jsak kv ksr k` min c5 juey fsw kulv kith, jvn thilv jv lust m5 d55t k` thilv m5 d55t m5 derv lu`k naath.

sourceString: Additionally, in some cases, the reopening of schools after a period of closure has resulted in increased infection rates.
targetString: Nysk, kv th11x gu1thn5, l2p du22lg]r` nysk kv ksr g1k`dv la n77xv f66 b5 luex loc th5n kv pek m5 d55t.

sourceString: As closures tend to occur concurrently with other interventions such as public gathering bans, it can be difficult to measure the specific impact of school closures.During the 1918-1919 influenza pandemic in the United States, school closures and public gathering bans were associated with lower total mortality rates.
targetString: Kv f66 la g1k du22lg]r` a tussk kvvl kv civx k]kivn cet kv f66 ba jv lar 5 /c5 naath nyuur kv bun, bumv vn f66 ba gssy g`k` du22lg]r` x1c. Kv run 1918-1919 m22 c5 yinpiluvndha kv fsw thi`x k` Yunaytet Y5tht22t, g1k du2l5g]r` kvn l7k nyuur` nath kv bun cua jv guic v jvn 2 jak li11 k` kuiy.

sourceString: Cities that implemented such interventions earlier had greater delays in reaching peak mortality rates.
targetString: R0k tin d5t tin ca kvn t5 cet kv vn titi k1m raar kv p0th la te kv kv bax t5 d55t kv f66 /c5 li1divn b5 cop k` pek m5 d55t.

sourceString: Schools closed for a median duration of 4 weeks according to a study of 43 US cities' response to the Spanish Flu.
targetString: Du2lg]r` t22 ca g1k kv gu11th m5 tst m5 cet kv juskn5 4 k`r] cet kv m5 ca lar v g6r x`c` k` w55 US t5 43 kv lu]cdivn kv Piluu Yithp00ny.

sourceString: School closures were shown to reduce morbidity from the Asian flu by 90% during the 1957–58 outbreak, and up to 50% in controlling influenza in the US, 2004–2008.Multiple countries successfully slowed the spread of infection through school closures during the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
targetString: G1k du22l5g]r` cua jv nyoth 5 cv d5t ju1th piluu Acia xok kv pek m5 cet kv 90% kv ru]]n 1957-58 me c5 juey ben rvi fsaa, k` cu pek m5 cet kv 50% kv g1x yinpiluvndha k` US kv run 2004-2008. W55 t5 xuan cua thi1x ju1th kv fsw lu`x kv xu]k kv f66 ca du2lg]r` g1k kv ru]]n 2009 kv thi1x H1N1 piluu kv fsw.

sourceString: School closures in the city of Oita, Japan, were found to have successfully decreased the number of infected students at the peak of infection; however closing schools was not found to have significantly decreased the total number of infected students.
targetString: G1k du2l5g]r` rvi wec Oita, Japan, cuv jssc 5 cv pek gan du22lg]r` tin cv moc juey jak` kuiy k` pek 2 cv k`p w5c kvvliw; kuv la f55 g1k du22lg]r` /cv jsc vn f66 derv xu]k ju1th kv rs jak` d5t v lvvl xu k` pek nath diaal tin cv k`p kv juey rvi gan tin gs11r.

sourceString: Mandatory school closures and other social distancing measures were associated with a 29% to 37% reduction in influenza transmission rates.
targetString: G1k dul2l5g]r` kvn diaal kvvl kvn f66 b5 naath nyuur kv kam cua jv guic v jvn thi11x ju1th k` pek k` 29% v we k` 37% kv xu]k yinpiluvndha kv pek 2 cv k`p.

sourceString: Early school closures in the United States delayed the peak of the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
targetString: G1k du22lg]r` kv p0th k` Yunaytet Y5tht22t cv d5t ju1th kv thi1x piluu H1N1 kv fsw kv ru]]n 2009 gax jsk.

sourceString: Despite the overall success of closing schools, a study of school closures in Michigan found that "district level reactive school closures were ineffective."During the swine flu outbreak in 2009 in the UK, in an article titled "Closure of schools during an influenza pandemic" published in the Lancet Infectious Diseases, a group of epidemiologists endorsed the closure of schools in order to interrupt the course of the infection, slow further spread and buy time to research and produce a vaccine.
targetString: C`x n5 m22 ca du2lg]r` g1k cet kv min g77rv, cu g6r x`c` kvl kv g1k du22lg]r` jv ben jek vn f66 min tussk kv ku5c g1k` du22lg]r` w5c /cv r6x. Kn thi1x ju1th piluu kv fsw kv ru]]n 2009 k` UK, rvi wargak` m5 csal 5 ‘g1k du2l5g]r` kv gu11th thi`x` yinpiluvndha kv fsw’ m5 be raar k` Lanthvt kv ku5c luex` ju1th, bu]n epidvm5lsj5th cu kv thaany 5 ba du2lg]r` g1k kv f66 ba luex ju1th xok, ba thi1xdv kv fsw jak` kuiy kvn f66 bv te kv gu11th m5 lu1x kv g6r x`c` k` ba w`l l1t.

sourceString: Having studied previous influenza pandemics including the 1918 flu pandemic, the influenza pandemic of 1957 and the 1968 flu pandemic, they reported on the economic and workforce effect school closure would have, particularly with a large percentage of doctors and nurses being women, of whom half had children under the age of 16.
targetString: Ks ksr k` m22 ca du]]p 2 thi`x ju1th yinpiluvndha t22 nhiam jv fsw jek, cet kv thi1x yinpiluvndha kv fsw kv 1918, yinpiluvndha 1957 kvn thi1x yinpiluvndha ruun` 1968 kv fsw, cu kvn v lar 5 eksnsmik kvn naath tin l`t kv g1k du22lg]r` derv te kv kvl kv pek m5 d55t k` k5mn5 kvn n``thn5 tin t] m`n, tin te nuthdivn kv gaat t5 te runkivn piny 16.

sourceString: They also looked at the dynamics of the spread of influenza in France during French school holidays and noted that cases of flu dropped when schools closed and re-emerged when they re-opened.
targetString: Cu kvn guic b` kv civx tin g66l kv thi1x ju1th yinpiluvndha kv fsw k` Pvrvvny kv n5n l]x` du22lg]r` k` Pvrvvny k` cua jv lar 5 c5 pek piluu ku00 m22 ca du2lg]r` g1k k` cuv rs nysk kv d5t m22 ca du2lg]r` nysk kv l2p.

sourceString: They noted that when teachers in Israel went on strike during the flu season of 1999–2000, visits to doctors and the number of respiratory infections dropped by more than a fifth and more than two fifths respectively.
targetString: Cu kvn v lar 5 m22 c5 xieec gan k` Yithvruvl xot kv we nhiam kv gu11th 2 c5 piluu ben kv 1999-2000, gu`l nath kv m5n5 kvn xuan ju1thn5 luex` l55k` cu kv ku00 k` dhieec kvn pek m5 rvw w55k` dhieec 5nsns.

sourceString: For schools and childcare facilities, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.
targetString: Kv ku5c du22lg]r` kvn gu1th yoop` gan, vn U.S. Thvntvr5 g1x ju1th kvn pendv ben cv jv lar 5 ba kv g1k kv gu11th m5 civk kv f66 ba kv yivc kvn f66 ba kv moc wal m5 cv te kv naath t5 cv moc juey t5 ben rvi tiecn5 du22lg]r` c`x /kenv fsw thi`x.

sourceString: When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as cancelling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.
targetString: M5 cv te kv thi1x ju1th kv wec kv gu11th m5 lvm kiv gu11th m5 tst, cu]x naath kv kam ba jv dhil l1th l`t cet kv gu]k j`l5 kv gu`l, du]]l5, kvn mat nath kv rs gu11th kvl kv lust d]divn cet ciaax yithpust kiv k2t din kiv mieth k00l k` kapt5ria, ba ksamn5 kamkivn jak` n1n, thaak ben` nath rvc kvn thaak jivvn`divn, xu]k nath tin gu` rvi du22lg]r`, kvn l1t gu1th pusl` pu11ny rvi du22lg]r` m5 b5 gaat tin ca guic cet te kv nyuuthn5 piluu we th5n.

sourceString: When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.
targetString: M5 cv te kv nyuuth m5 jsc vn f66 dsap kv rvi wec, kvvl kv c`p nyuur` nath kv kam, derv gsaa 5 d22 du2lg]r` k1p cu]x.

sourceString: On 26 January, China instituted measures to contain the COVID-19 outbreak which included extending the Spring Festival holiday to contain the outbreak.

sourceString: Universities and schools around the country closed.

sourceString: On 23 February, Iran's Ministry of Health announced the closure of universities, higher educational institutions and schools in several cities and provinces.

sourceString: On 3 March, UNESCO released the first global numbers on school closures and affected students.

sourceString: It reported that 13 countries had enacted preventive measures including the temporary closure of schools and universities, impacting 290.5 million students around the world.

sourceString: In reaction, UNESCO called on countries to support affected students and families and facilitate large-scale inclusive distance learning programmes.

sourceString: On 4 March, the Italian government ordered the full closure of all schools and universities nationwide as Italy reached 100 deaths.

sourceString: On 5 March, the majority of learners affected by COVID-19 emergency measures were located in China, with 233 million learners affected, followed by Japan at 16.5 million and Iran at 14.5 million.

sourceString: By 10 March, one in five students worldwide was "staying away from school due to the COVID-19 crisis" while another one in four was barred from higher education institutions.

sourceString: On 13 March, governments in 49 countries announced or implemented school closures, including 39 countries which closed schools nationwide and 22 countries with localised school closures.

sourceString: By 19 March, 50% of students worldwide were affected by school closures, corresponding to nationwide closures in 102 countries and local closures in 11 countries affecting 850 million children and youth.

sourceString: By 20 March, over 70% of the world's learners were impacted by closures, with 124 country-wide school closures.

sourceString: On 23 March, all Nigerian school were found to have been closed down by Nigerian government, markets as well as companies were closed down and children were forbidden by parents to step out of their homes.

sourceString: On 26 March, all New Zealand schools and universities have been closed down across the country.

sourceString: Until April 6, holidays were extended in all secondary schools of Turkmenistan.

sourceString: An order signed by the Ministry of Education as a preventative measure aims to prevent the spread of respiratory diseases in connection with the WHO coronavirus pandemic.

sourceString: 10 countries have localised schools closures, UNESCO estimates  473,933,356  learners are potentially at risk (pre-primary to upper-secondary education) and 77,938,904 learners are potentially at risk in tertiary education.

sourceString: Note: Figures correspond to total number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8] who could be affected should localised closures become countrywide.
targetString: Ruac m5 ba tit: Vn pek vmv naxv rs kv pek gan tin ca gs1r piny k` pre-primar5, primar5, thkvnd22r5 min tst kvn thvkvnd22r5 min d55t [kv pek ISCED k` 0 v we k` 3], kvvl kv pek du22lg]r` ter5civr5 [kv pek ISCED 5 v we k` 8] tin c5 ji``k g`k` du22lg]r` kv cop m5 ca du2lg]r` g1k rvi wec kvvliw.

sourceString: Enrolment figures based on latest UNESCO Institute of Statistics data.

sourceString: School closures in response to the COVID-19 pandemic have shed a light on numerous issues affecting access to education, as well as broader socio-economic issues.

sourceString: The disruptions they cause affect people across communities, but their impact is more severe for disadvantaged children and their families including interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems and consequent economic cost to families who cannot work.

sourceString: Working parents are more likely to miss work when schools close in order to take care of their children, incurring wage loss in many instances and negatively impacting productivity.

sourceString: Women often represent a large share of health-care workers and often cannot attend work because of childcare obligations that result from school closures.

sourceString: In response to school closures caused by COVID-19, UNESCO recommends the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.To aid in slowing the transmission of COVID-19, hundreds of libraries have temporarily closed.

Kv f66 ba lu`k th6p kv g1x COVID-19 kv d6pdv kv naath, ca du2l buskn5 t5 kur g1k kv gu11th m5 civk.

sourceString: In the United States, numerous major cities announced public library closures, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, and New York City, affecting 221 libraries.

sourceString: A 1974 report by the World Bank defined formal education as the following:Formal education: the hierarchically structured, chronologically graded ‘education system’, running from primary school through the university and including, in addition to general academic studies, a variety of specialised programmes and institutions for full-time technical and professional training.The majority of data collected on the number of students and learners impacted by COVID-19 has been calculated based on the closure of formal education systems.

sourceString: Students enrolled in higher education programmes at colleges, universities, and community colleges are often refereed to in countries such as United States as "college students."The closure of colleges and universities has widespread implications for students, faculty, administrators, and the institutions themselves.

G1k kslijn5 kvn yunvb7thvt5n5 cv rivk m5 d55t n66x k` gaat tin g]r, pakult5n5, mukt`pn5 ru5c` kvn kvn yinitht5tucin5 pu1nykivn.

sourceString: Colleges and universities across the United States have been called upon to issue refunds to students for the cost of tuition and room and board.

sourceString: In the United States of America, Colleges and universities operate as "mini-cities" which generate significant revenue for cities, states, and regions.

sourceString: For example, Princeton University contributed $1.58 billion USD to the New Jersey economy and students spent about $60 million in off-campus spending.

sourceString: College and university closures have a domino effect on economies with far-reaching implications.According to Linda Bilmes of the Harvard Kennedy School, "local hotels, restaurants, cafes, shops, car rental agencies and other local businesses obtain a significant share of annual revenue from graduation week and college reunions...

Cet kv m22 ca lar Linda Bilmes k` du2lg]r` Harard Kenedy, hotel5 rvi wec, rvthtvrvn5, thukn5, gu1th ju]r thurbivvl5 kvn g`pvn5 k]kivn la jek kvn pek m5 gsaa kv n5n thuk` nath du22lg]r` kv ru]]n kvn nysak mat` kslij...

sourceString: these communities will suffer a lot of economic damage if the colleges remain closed at that time."Small towns which rely on college students to support the local economy and provide labour to local businesses are especially impacted by school closures and the exodus of students from campus.

R0k tin tsatn5 tin jek du]]r k` gaat tin g]r kv we nhiam eksnsmik`divn k` th7p l1t k` naath tin j5 wec kv g`pvn5 bv ji``k kv kv vn g1k du22lg]r` nvmv kvn jivvn nath tin g]r k` ksmp1th.

sourceString: In Ithaca, New York, Cornell University students spent at least $4 million a week in Tompkins county.

sourceString: In the wake of Cornell's decision to keep students home following spring break and transition to virtual instruction, the Mayor of Ithaca called for "immediate and forceful federal action — we will see a horrific economic impact as a result of Cornell University closing."

sourceString: UNESCO is sharing 10 recommendations during this period:
targetString: UNESCO jvn nyuaakv l``r5 d1x 10 kv naath kv jvn gu11th vmv:

sourceString: Examine the readiness and choose the most relevant tools: Decide on the use high-technology and low-technology solutions based on the reliability of local power supplies, internet connectivity, and digital skills of teachers and students.
targetString: Thvmv rial5k` nath kv r] k` bv du]]p in dee gsaa kuany: C`rv jssk` ciaax in d22 l`t kv naath kv t0knslj5 in d55t kv du]]p in d22 x`th v gu11th in xun bu]m rvi wec, intvrnvt kvn c11p dij5tsl k` xieec kvn gaat tin g]r.

sourceString: This could range through integrated digital learning platforms, video lessons, MOOCs, to broadcasting through radios and TVs.
targetString: Jvn derv tussk k` mat dij5tsl kvn kv du]]p x55c`, lvthvn5 kv b5di6, MOOKn5, kv th7p l``r5 kv radivw kvn TV.

sourceString: Ensure inclusion of the distance learning programmes: Implement measures to ensure that students including those with disabilities or from low-income backgrounds have access to distance learning programmes, if only a limited number of them have access to digital devices.

sourceString: Consider temporarily decentralising such devices from computer labs to families and support them with internet connectivity.

sourceString: WHEREAS on March 4, 2020, I proclaimed a State of Emergency to exist in California as a result of the threat of COVID-19;

sourceString: NOW, THEREFORE, I, GAVIN NEWSOM, Governor of the State of California, in accordance with the authority vested in me by the State Constitution and statutes of the State of California, and in particular, Government Code sections 8567, 8627, and 8665 do hereby issue the following Order to become effective immediately:
targetString: VN T~MV, KV KU%C VMS, F~N GAVIN NEWSOM, ku``r m5dh55r wec California, cet kv min laar lu1xv in ca k1m f` v xut wec kvn pek wec California, kiv v civk, kv kssd kuumv 8567,8627 kvn 8665, laar` titi kv f66 ba kv l1th l`t kv p0th:

sourceString: IT IS HEREBY ORDERED THAT:
targetString: CA JV LAR VN F^^:

sourceString: 1) To preserve the public health and safety, and to ensure the healthcare delivery system is capable of serving all, and prioritizing those at the highest risk and vulnerability, all residents are directed to immediately heed the current State public health directives, which I ordered the Department of Public Health to develop for the current statewide status of COVID-19.
targetString: 1) KV g6r k` f66 ba ciaax pusl` pu11ny jak` gsaa kvn mal nath, kvn f66 ba jv x`th vn f66 gsaa ciaax in th6p kv l1t pusl` pu11ny kv jv x1c, k` ba naath tin thi1k kv rivk vms tit kvn thi1kdivn kv rivk, naath diaal tin ciex w5c v kv tiit rik tin tussk t`mv kv ku5 pusl` pu11ny, tin c` l1r mukt`p pusl` pu11ny nath diaal vn f66 gu]]r v wec kvvliw kv ku5c g1x ju1th COVID-19.

sourceString: Those directives are consistent with the March 19, 2020, Memorandum on Identification of Essential Critical Infrastructure Workers During COVID-19 Response, found at: https://covid19.ca.gov/.

sourceString: ORDER OF THE STATE PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICER
targetString: L~~R WEC IN BE K~ L~~T MUKT~P~ PUSL~ PU!!NY

sourceString: To protect public health, I as State Public Health Officer and Director of the California Department of Public Health order all individuals living in the State of California to stay home or at their place of residence except as needed to maintain continuity of operations of the federal critical infrastructure sectors, as outlined at https://www.cisa.gov/critical-infrastructure-sectors.
targetString: Kv f66 ba ciaax pusl` pu11ny nath diaal gax, F~N cet kv l``t mukt`p` pusl` pu11ny j5 wec California k` mukt`p pusl` pu11ny c` l11t diaal tin ciex k` California ji6k 5 b5 kv nyuur ci22xn5kivn kiv gu1thn5 tin civx kvn kv vn5 m5 cv jssc vn f66 g6r kv loc th5n civvx` v kummv p2dvrsl v th0ktsr in nyooth ciaax l1t, cet kv min ca lar k` https://www.cisa.gov/critical-infrastructure-sectors.

sourceString: In addition, and in consultation with the Director of the Governor's Office of Emergency Services, I may designate additional sectors as critical in order to protect the health and well-being of all Californians.
targetString: Nysk, kvvl kv dayr0ktsr mukt`p` kuumv kv ku5c rik` m5 rup-rup, F`n th0ktsr d]divn jak` l`t v la gu55c kv f66 bv ciaax pusl` pu11ny gax kvn mal nath k` j5 California diaal.

sourceString: Pursuant to the authority under the Health and Safety Code 120125, 120140, 131080, 120130(c), 120135, 120145, 120175 and 120150, this order is to go into effect immediately and shall stay in effect until further notice.
targetString: Cet kv min te rvi lu`x` mukt`p` pusl` pu11ny kvn code civvx` mal` 120125, 120140, 131080, 120130(c), 120135, 120145, 120175 and 120150, kvn 120150, l``r vmv bv we l`t kv p0th k` bv te th5n am`n5 m5 c5 l``r d]divn ben raar.

sourceString: The federal government has identified 16 critical infrastructure sectors whose assets, systems, and networks, whether physical or virtual, are considered so vital to the United States that their incapacitation or destruction would have a debilitating effect on security, economic security, public health or safety, or any combination thereof.
targetString: Kuumv p2dvrsl cv dup 16 t5 gsw k1m raar kv th0ktsr5 t5 tin l`t kv kv, c1p l1tdivn, kv nvtw`kn5 m5 kv tin thi1k kiv l1t kv v ns1n, ca kv guic kv nyin teek` k` Yunaytet Y5tht22t vn f66 gssydivn k` th5ki77r5t5, eksnsmik th5ki7r5t5, ciaax pusl` pu11ny weckvvliw kvn ciaax mal`, kiv matdivn kvvl kvn tiit diaal.

sourceString: I order that Californians working in these 16 critical infrastructure sectors may continue their work because of the importance of these sectors to Californians' health and well-being.

sourceString: This Order is being issued to protect the public health of Californians.

sourceString: The California Department of Public Health looks to establish consistency across the state in order to ensure that we mitigate the impact of COVID-19.

sourceString: Our goal is simple, we want to bend the curve, and disrupt the spread of the virus.

sourceString: The supply chain must continue, and Californians must have access to such necessities as food, prescriptions, and health care.

sourceString: When people need to leave their homes or places of residence, whether to obtain or perform the functions above, or to otherwise facilitate authorized necessary activities, they should at all times practice social distancing.

sourceString: 2) The healthcare delivery system shall prioritize services to serving those who are the sickest and shall prioritize resources, including personal protective equipment, for the providers providing direct care to them.

sourceString: This Order is not intended to, and does not, create any rights or benefits, substantive or procedural, enforceable at law or in equity, against the State of California, its agencies, departments, entities, officers, employees, or any other person.

sourceString: The SARS-CoV-2 virus is the cause of COVID-19 (coronavirus disease 2019), a contagious respiratory disease that was first identified in December 2019, in Wuhan, Hubei, China.
targetString: Vn SARS-CoV-2 bayr`th v jvn la tuk COVID-19 (juey ksrsnabayr`th 2019) juey luex` m5 k``p li11k nath m5 tusk n2ndv kv pay w`lrvw 2019, k` Wuhan, Hubei, China.

sourceString: The disease is a type of coronavirus, the same family that includes SARS, MERS, and some varieties of the common cold.

sourceString: It was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) on 11 March 2020.

sourceString: While much about COVID-19 is still unknown, preliminary data suggests that it is more virulent and contagious than the seasonal flu, and less virulent but more contagious than SARS and MERS.

sourceString: Due to the spread of the disease, you are advised not to travel unless necessary, to avoid being infected, quarantined, or stranded by changing restrictions and cancelled flights.

sourceString: This is not just to protect you, but also those you come in contact with.

sourceString: As it happens, you probably aren't missing much by staying home, as many attractions around the world are closing their doors to avoid spreading the disease.

sourceString: If you do need to travel, take precautions as you would for other infections: wash your hands frequently, avoid touching your face, cough and sneeze into your elbow or a tissue, and avoid contact with sick people.

sourceString: Before traveling, read up on the extensive and fast-changing array of travel restrictions that have been imposed around the world.

sourceString: Transportation from long-distance passenger flights to local buses has been curtailed or completely shut down in many countries due to low demand or government orders.
